In view of the conditions prevailing due to COVID-19, the pre-bid can be made online too. The last date for downloading and submitting RFQ has been fixed at June 5.

It is pertinent to mention here that for redevelopment of about 24.5 acre area of Dehradun railway station and around it, the Mussoorie Dehradun Development Authority (MDDA) had held a series of meetings with the railways last year and had worked on inception report, situation analysis, feasibility study and other aspects. Following the approval of the state administration, the MDDA and RLDA had signed a memorandum of understanding in December last year.

As part of the Dehradun railway station redevelopment project, the railway station will be developed into a heritage station.

The project will also include establishment of railway museum, hotels, kids zone and commercial complex in addition to parking facility and developing the current Mussoorie bus stand outside the railway station in a new form.

The project is to be undertaken in the public private partnership (PPP) mode. It is worth mentioning here that this redevelopment project is expected to resolve traffic congestion at the railway station and nearby areas while also facilitating beautification of the area to provide a better environment to the public.

Title: C’garh races to contain Covid-19 in Katghora hotspot
Article:
Katghora town in Chhattisgarh’s Korba district, is among the 170 hotspots across the country, which has been earmarked as a ‘Red zone’.

The town of Katghora had until now contributed exactly 75% or 27 out of the 36 people stricken by the Covid-19 pathogen in Chhattisgarh and 10 of the active patients who are still being treated at the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS), Raipur.

Notably, a hotspot or a red zone is earmarked to map the local transmission of the disease and prevent the contagion from spreading.

On one hand, a complete clampdown has been enforced in the town and its outskirts, on the other, the health department has ramped-up screening of each and every person in Katghora.

Strict restrictions on the movement of people and goods to and from the town have been put in place in the entire area to prevent any further spread of the virus, Korba district magistrate Kiran Kaushal told The Pioneer.

She further informed that “to monitor the movement of people closely, two separate war-rooms have been set-up in the district--one in the district collectorate at the district headquarters, while the other is at the containment spot of Katghora,” she said.

“We conduct electronic surveillance, like checking mobile phone locations on GPS and check the footages of CCTV cameras installed inside the confined area,” the district magistrate said.

Special vigil is put at the Purani Basti neighbourhood of Katghora, which has become an epicenter after a 16-year-old boy, linked to Tablighi Jamaat congregation was detected as the first Covid-19 positive person on April 4, the district administrative chief said.

Soon after the boy tested positive for the virus, 26 other people who had been in contact with him also tested positive for Covid-19, she said.

The DM further said: “Electronic surveillance was also being used to ensure that the primary radius of 3 km in the infection epicenter of Purani Basti area, is sealed round the clock with a drone monitoring system to ensure no one steps out from their homes at all”.

To a question if she was facing any resistance from the symptomatic and quarantined people for testing, the DM said:“Nothing much, which is worth mentioning.”

Meanwhile, a health bulletin issued by the state health department, said that health teams have been deployed for screening each and every person in Katghora to identify symptomatic people who will be further monitored to contain the outbreak.

Followed by the guidelines from the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel had ordered for rapid antibody tests of all the residents of Katghora who are at present being tested with fast-track kits.

Title: 9-month pregnant woman leading fight against corona in Kondagaon
Article:
A heavily-pregnant woman has emerged as a leading corona warrior in Naxal-hit Kondagaon district.

She has been working tirelessly to ensure people remain indoors and stay protected from the coronavirus outbreak.

Santoshi Manikpuri (38), who is already a mother of a four-year-old daughter, was given the title of 'champion of change’ last month by the Kondagaon district administration, is an auxiliary nurse midwife (ANM).

At present, she is posted at the health and wellness centre (HWC) in Kerawahi village of the insurgency-hit Kondagaon district in tribal-dominated Bastar division. She has been in the post for the last five years.

"There are very few instances in life where you get an opportunity to serve people at a crucial time. I could have taken leave. But, I listened to the call of my soul that I should fulfill my duty as a health worker,” Santoshi told PTI over phone.

The ANM and two other staff members from the HWC, not only handle patients in the OPD, but after finishing their work, they go from village to village to make people aware about social distancing and personnel hygiene.

"Being a senior ANM, it is my responsibility to be on duty. Officials had asked me to take leave if I need, but I want to work till I can,” said Santoshi, whose child is due next month.

"We are continuously monitoring the situation in our area and have asked people to inform when anyone comes from other states or from abroad," she said.

So far, members from 50 families, mostly migrant workers, who returned here from the other coronavirus-affected states, were quarantined at their homes and they have completed their observation period, she said.

"We also hold meetings of 'mitanins' (community health workers), who are helping in the awareness drive and inform us about sick people, to keep them informed about the government's guidelines in this regard," she said.

In her endeavour, Santoshi has received support from her husband, who is taking care of their four-year-old daughter at home.

Title: Nehru Yuva Kendra contributes in fight against Covid-19
Article:
The Nehru Yuva Kendra Sangathan, Raipur along with the UNICEF on Tuesday trained more than 300 national volunteers of the state.

During the training, prevention of Covid-19, its awareness, facts and myths, and misconceptions were discussed, a release by the organization said.

The training session was conducted by the officials of the organisation and experts from the UNICEF.

The objectives of the training were to create a strong working team to control the spread of coronavirus in the rural area, said Shrikant Pandey, state director, Nehru Yuva Kendra Sangathan.

“When the lockdown will be lifted, we will have to be more vigilant so that effective measures can be taken to prevent the virus from spreading again in the community. In such a scenario, a team of trained youths will prove to be very useful,” he said.

Abhishek Singh, an expert from the UNICEF, while addressing the youngsters, said that the personal cleanliness is the first and foremost.

He shared the effective technique with the participants how to wash and sanitize hands through a video presentation.

He also them that it was not necessary to wash hands with hand wash or sanitizer, hands can be washed with any soap or detergent for at least 40 seconds.

More than 23 lakh Covid-19 cases have been reported across the world, of which 15,000 cases have been reported in India so far, said Dr Gajendra, an expert from the UNICEF.

However, out of the 36 cases in Chhattisgarh, 24 patients have been recovered whereas 12 patients are still under treatment, he said.

Arpit Tiwari, district youth coordinator, Nehru Yuva Kendra, Raipur, advised youngsters to stay away from false news and misconceptions prevalent on WhatsApp and other social media platforms.

Dr Chitra, a specialist of the UNICEF motivated youngsters to stay healthy and stay safe.

Explaining the importance of Yoga to them, Chitra said that they themselves should practice Yoga to encourage their family members and acquaintances.

Many activities are being carried out by the Nehru Yuva Kendra at different levels such as writing wall graffiti, distribution of masks, and awareness campaign on social media platforms, said Nitin Sharma, Durg district youth coordinator.

Himanshu Gupta, Anjali and other district officials of the organisation were also present at the training session.

Title: Ensure ventilators, ICUs in mountain & COVID-19 hospitals within a week: HC
Article:
The High Court of Uttarakhand has directed that ventilators and intensive care units (ICUs) should be set up in hospitals in mountainous regions and 15 other hospitals for treatment of COVID-19 within seven days. The court clarified that the government cannot be given more than one week for doing the needful though if there is any problem, the government can approach the court. Hearing the matter, the division bench of justice Sudhanshu Dhulia and justice Ravindra Maithani has set the next date of hearing on April 29.

It will be recalled that advocate Dushyant Mainali had filed a public interest litigation seeking proper facilities for doctors and ensuring their safety in view of the COVID-19 pandemic. The petitioner has also questioned the safety arrangements for doctors and medical staff in the state.

He has contended that doctors and associated staff handling COVID-19 related work were provided HIV kits instead of personal protection equipment (PPE) kits, adding that the HIV kits are not suitable for protection from COVID-19. Mainali also informed the court that the government had sent 1,000 substandard PPE kits to the Sushila Tiwari government medical college in Haldwani.

Stating that the company which provided such kits had played with the safety of medical staff, the petitioner has demanded that the matter be investigated and a case be lodged. He has also contended that the hospital which have been authorised for treatment of COVID-19 patients lack both ventilators and ICUs whereas both these are vital in the treatment of COVID-19 patients.

Title: Expired chemicals being sprayed in Manglaur, allege councillors
Article:
Councillors of Manglaur municipality found containers of various chemicals well past the expiry date in a municipality building. Accusing the municipality chairman and executive officer of irregularities, they alleged that expired chemicals were being sprayed in the town for sanitisation in view of the COVID-19 pandemic. On being informed about the discovery, the sector magistrate reached the site, sealed the containers taking them into his possession.

As in other parts of the state, the local body in Manglaur has also been spraying disinfectants to reduce the risk of COVID-19 spray in the town. On Tuesday, about a dozen councillors found various chemicals past their expiry date being kept in the old premises of the municipality. They alleged that such chemicals were being used for sanitising the town posing a threat to public health. They cited bottles filled with various such chemicals in the municipality room. The municipality executive officer Shahid Ali said that the complaint of the councillors had been received and is being investigated. Averring that this was a political conspiracy, he said that he has sought an explanation from the store-keeper, adding that action will be taken against the guilty.

Manglaur MLA Qazi Nizamuddin said that the culprit should be booked under the National Security Act if found guilty of such serious negligence towards public health in view of COVID-19 pandemic. He said that he had talked to cabinet minister Madan Kaushik, Urban Development secretary Shailesh Bagauli and Roorkee joint magistrate Banani Bansal, adding that all had assured strict action against the guilty.

Title: COVID test rate 21.2 per 1 lakh pop in U’khand
Article: Amid concern over the COVID-19 testing facilities and need for more tests to combat the disease, the health department of Uttarakhand revealed on Tuesday that the testing rate for COVID-19 in the State is at 21.2 per one lakh of the population. There is a marked district wise disparity in this figure. The health department data shows that the sample collection rate in Dehradun is 71 per lakh which is highest in the State. In the district 1275 samples have so far been collected for COVID-19 test. The testing rate is 52 and 51 per lakh in Nainital and Haridwar districts. In Haridwar, 1065 samples have so far been collected while 669 samples of suspected patients have been collected in Nainital district. The lab of medical college Haldwani has so far testes 2189 samples of suspected patients while the laboratory of All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Rishikesh has tested 1236 samples. The Ahuja lab (private), Dehradun, has so far tested 61 samples of suspected patients.

Title: No change in date of Kedarnath reopening
Article:
The Kedarnath shrine will be reopened for the summer on April 29 as scheduled earlier. While the date for reopening Badrinath shrine has been deferred from April 30 to May 15, Kedarnath will be reopened as decided earlier. This decision was taken by the Kedarnath Rawal (chief priest) Bhima Shankar Lingam and others at Ukhimath on Tuesday.

Welcoming this decision, the Devbhumi Teerth Purohit Hakhukukdharri Mahapanchayat expressed gratefulness to the Rawal, Teerth Purohits and traditional right holders connected to the Kedarnath shrine.

The Mahapanchayat spokesman Brijesh Sati said that the erstwhile king of Tehri, Manujendra Shah should also consider reopening Badrinath shrine on the date decided earlier.

He opined that the state government’s way of functioning is responsible for the issues being faced regarding reopening of the portals of Badrinath and Kedarnath.

It had been decided on Vasant Pachami that Badrinath would be reopened on April 30 while on Shivratri it had been decided that Kedarnath would be reopened on April 29. He questioned why the State government and the Devsthanam Board failed to bring back the Rawals of these two shrines back to the state on time though the dates for reopening of the shrines had been decided about three months ago.

Badrinath Rawal & assistants test negative for COVID-19

Title: Badrinath Rawal & assistants test -ve for COVID-1
Article:
The first sample test reports of the Badrinath Rawal, Ishwari Prasad Namboodri and his three assistants have come out negative. All India Institute of Medical Sciences Rishikesh issued these reports.

The Uttarakhand Char Dham Devsthanam Board media in-charge Harish Gaur stated that information had been received from AIIMS Rishikesh about the Rawal and his assistants appear to be healthy. However, the Rawal has been advised to remain under home quarantine in Rishikesh till May 4. After that his second sample test will be conducted to check for novel coronavirus (COVID-19).

The Rawal will depart for Joshimath after the second test report is received.

It will be recalled here that the date of reopening Badrinath was deferred from April 30 to May 15 due to the situation resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. The Rawal was recently brought to Uttarakhand from his native village in Kerala.

Title: Payment of Rs 900 Cr to farmers during lockdown period: Minister
Article:
State agriculture and water resources minister Choubey on Tuesday said under the guidance of Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel, special attention is being paid to agriculture and allied activities during the lockdown.

Addressing media persons through video conference he said strengthening the rural economy, the state government is continuously working for the development of villages, the poor and the farmers.

Choubey further said that under the crop insurance and Pradhan Mantri Kisan Yojana, an amount of Rs 900 crore has been transferred to their accounts so far during the lockdown.

The state government has also ensured the sale of their produce along with discounts for farming.

Choubey said the payment of Rabi crop insurance to the farmers has also started.

An amount of Rs 2 crore 59 lakh has been released to 2668 farmers of Kabirdham, Mungeli and Balrampur districts of the state, he said.

Farmers of other districts of the state will also be paid the insurance amount of Rabi crops soon, he said and added that the Union petroleum ministry permitted the food corporation of India to make bio-ethanol from food grains and Chhattisgarh is expected to get permission to manufacture bio-ethanol soon.

A provision of Rs 5,300 crore has been made under the Rajiv Gandhi Kisan Nyay Yojana launched in the state for the benefit of farmers which will be distributed from next May to all the farmers, who sold paddy at the minimum support price in the state, he said.

With the aim of employing villagers in on a large scale, the work of the watershed mission has also been started by the state agriculture department.

The minister further said that in view of the upcoming kharif season, the preparation has been started by the agriculture department.

Adequate quantity of seeds has been stored, he said and added food grain and other commodities have been stored in the state.

Care is being taken to ensure that the farmers do not face any problem in the farming during the lockdown period and the upcoming kharif season, he said.

Title: Yes to life and no to death: Sunderlal Bahuguna
Article:
Noted environmentalist and Padma Vibhushan recipient Sunderlal Bahuguna asked his fellow countrymen to follow the guidelines issued to contain the spread of COVID- 19.

In a message inscribed on a photograph of his visit to Natraj, the green bookshop in the eighties, Bahuguna wrote, “Say Yes to Life and No to Death”. Later speaking to Upendra Arora, the owner of the bookshop, Bahuguna said we all need to stand united to defeat the virus. He felt that the final answer to such life threatening issues and the way to stay alive is to respect the rights of planet earth.

Bahuguna has always urged the new generation to love, conserve and protect the natural heritage. He said he would like everyone to utilise their time at home to read and learn as much as they can about our forests and wildlife. In order to stay protected human kind will require to draw lessons to live in harmony with nature, he added. He deeply feels that the present global scenario has occurred to make us understand the harmony of one true connection between man and nature, which was alienated over the years. He felt that whenever and where the environment was indiscriminately destroyed the human inhabitants have invariably suffered.

Title: Partial industrial, agricultural activities permitted in state
Article:
State labour secretary cum labour commissioner and nodal officer Sonmoni Borah on Tuesday permitted industrial and agricultural activities across the state, except in Covid-19 contamination zones and hotspots.

The permission will provide relief for migrant workers in industries, agriculture, construction and other work, other employment generating units by making them operational under the Standard Operating Process (SOP), an official order said.

It will also pave way for the transport of workers from relief camps to their working places.

Raipur collector Dr S Bharatidasan, however, said that the relaxation will not be enforced in the district’s hotspots and contamination zones.

All migrant workers staying in relief camps or other accommodations will be registered based on their vocation by the district administration, the collector said.

Based on the capability, these workers will be provided employment through placement in the district level industries and other employment generating activities, he said.

“If they are interested to work in places of earlier employment, it will be arranged. After health check-ups of the workers, if they are found to be healthy, then only they will be allowed to move to other districts,” the collector said.

The migrant workers will be allowed to travel within the district or inter-district limits but within will not be allowed to travel out of the state, the order said.

Vehicles to transport workers will have to be fully sanitized and social distancing will have to be maintained, it said.

Food and pure drinking water will be provided to the workers by the local administration while they are travelling. All coronavirus protocols issued by the Centre and the state government will have to be strictly implemented, the order said.

Title: State will remember AS Bisht for his social work: CM
Article:
The State will always feel the loss caused by the demise of Anand Singh Bisht. The works he had done for social welfare will always be remembered, said the Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat. He said this after paying homage to mortal remains of Bisht- the father of Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath- at the cremation site in Fulchatti in Pauri district on Tuesday.

Attending the cremation and consoling the bereaved family, Rawat wished them strength to face the loss. Vidhan Sabha speaker Prem Chand Aggarwal, cabinet minister Madan Kaushik, State minister Dhan Singh Rawat, Pauri MP Teerath Singh Rawat, MLA Mahendra Bhatt, Yoga guru Ramdev, OSD to the UP CM, Raj Bhushan Singh Rawat and the additional resident commissioner of UP Saumya Srivastava also paid their tributes to the departed social worker.

Title: CM directs Bijapur collector to probe into minor girl's death
Article:
Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel on Tuesday directed the Bijapur collector to probe into the death of a 12-year old girl from Aded village in the district and submit a report on the incident.

The minor girl Jamlo Madkam died from suspected dehydration after walking for more than 100 km from Telangana to Chhattisgarh among with 11 other people from her village.

The group had gone to the neighbouring state for plucking chillies, reports said.

Baghel has also hiked the compensation amount from Rs 1 lakh to Rs 5 lakh.

Earlier on Monday, the chief minister expressing deep grief over demise had sanctioned Rs 1 lakh as immediate relief to the next of kin from the Chief Minister’s Relief Fund. A

Meanwhile, the state government is providing all assistance to the workers in the state during the lockdown period.

Under the MNGREA, collection of tendu leaves and work in gauthans have restarted to generate employment to a large cross section of rural people.

The state government has provided food and boarding for more than 1.85 lakh migrant workers within the state and from other states.

The state government has constituted a team for constant monitoring of relief to stranded workers.

Title: Bokaro Admin chalks out safety plans post lockdown
Article:
District Administration Bokaro has started preparing for life after the lockdown ends, chalking out plans to curtail COVID-19 spread as a large number of people will return to the State.

“Administration is working hard on virus risk mitigation plans and regarding the management of the people, who will return after lockdown in the district. Including social distancing, remote working and to ensure business survival we are planning where to keep those people (who returned from other states),” said an official.

A meeting was held under the chairmanship of Deputy Commissioner Bokaro Mukesh Kumar regarding their management, their food including others on Monday. Kumar directed the District Disaster Management Officer Shakti Kumar for its earliest preparedness.

Wearing masks, isolated workspaces and remote working will be a norm when the lockdown eases up, the DC said.

“I have issued orders with immediate effect. It mandatory for every resident of the district, who is required to move out of the house due to urgent work, to wear a mask and comply with social distancing,” said Kumar.

He said that if any person is found outside wearing masks and violating social distancing, then strict legal action will be taken against them.

“If the mask is not available, self-made masks or towel and handkerchiefs etc. can also be used,” added Kumar.

“All the office bearers and police officers of the district and the heads of all other public sector undertakings and private companies are requested to ensure strict compliance in their establishments as well as in their areas even at their own level,” said the DC.

Kumar appealed to peopleto stay indoors and follow the lockdown strictly to prevent the spread of COVID-19. “People should venture out only in cases of emergency and purchase essential commodities. They should return home as soon as the purchase is done and not linger on roads,” he added.

During the meeting Kumar said, the Chief Minister Dal Bhat Center and the Chief Minister Didi Kitchen should be run in a better manner so that the needy do not have to face any problem.

Food grains (ration) up to May have been made available at all PDS centers. He asked the officials to make it ensure within two days that 100 percent ration has been distributed.

The SDOs were directed to fixed the rate of food items and provide a list, so that it can be facilitated. At the same time it was also directed that surprise raids and stock count (of rations) should also be conducted.

In order to make the lockdown fully effective, all the borders adjoining the district have been completely sealed. Only entry of vehicle carrying food items will be allowed, he said.

Kumar said, officials should ensure that continuous sanitization in the urban and rural areas of the district are made smoothly so that the spread of COVID-19 infection can be avoided.

A large number of CCTV cameras have been installed in the affected areas to keep an eye on the people so that the movement of the people can be constantly monitored. Special attention is being taken through the CCTV camera to ensure that there is no unnecessary movement of outsiders, he said.

If anybody needs a ration packet for Rs 525 is available which also includes children's entertainment items. Assuming the basis of five members in a family, the packet is made available which include toys, drawing books and others in addition to the ration for doorstep delivery, he said.

Beside others, Deputy Development Commissioner Ravi Ranjan Mishra, Additional Collector Vijay Kumar Gupta, Additional Municipal Commissioner Chas Shashi Prakash Jha, Civil Surgeon AK Pathak, District Supply Officer Sadat Anwar, District Transport Officer Santosh Kumar Garg were present in the meeting.

Title: Lockdown impact: Tribals to make ‘Bishu Shikar’ a symbolic affair
Article:
Amidst ongoing lockdown and threat of spread of coronavirus, tribals are planning to make Bishu Shikar to be a symbolic affair on May 4.

The apex body, Dolma Buru Sendra Samity (DBSS), has announced that the festival, also known as Sendra, would be celebrated on May 4 at Dalma wildlife sanctuary.

DBSS head Rakesh Hembrom said the festival was being celebrated for over a century now and they have decided to organise the rituals on May 4.

“Amidst ongoing lockdown and the risk associated with the virus we want to make Bishu Shikar a symbolic event. Barring the customary puja on the foothills on May 2, the celebration will be without hunting animals,”he added.

According to him, they would assemble near Fadlugora along NH 33 for puja and then shoot arrows as a symbol for Sendra. “We have asked the participants from Jharkhand, Bengal and Odisha to not come for the festival,”he said.

Hembrom said there is no need for hunting. Instead, the need of the hour is to wipe out the deadly coronavirus.

Assistant conservator of forest R.P. Singh said though DBSS chief priest Hembrom has assured him they would keep the tradition symbolic but they will continue to keep an eye on the movement of tribals.

The samiti would also appeal to all the tribal organisations in the next couple of days to not kill animals during Sendra but observe token rituals.

Jointly with the Dhalbhum forest division, the samiti would also chalk out the cultural and other programmes to be oranised on the day of the festival to attract the tribals.

“We are hopeful that the tribals would wake up early in the morning and worship their deities but will not go ahead for hunting as the senior functionaries of the Sendra Samiti has assured us about their plans,"noted an official.

It may be mentioned that every year, the forest department tries to aware villagers about the importance of wildlife and animals but still dozens of animals including deer, boar and wild buffaloes are killed during. Clad with hunting weapons like bows and arrows, they go into the jungle in search of animals by beating drums and chanting of holy hymns.

Meanwhile, the forest department is geared up to stop the tribals from hunting wild animals. Eleven strategic locations have been identified where members of Eco Club and villagers would be deployed to convince the tribals not to go for hunting.

Title: Palamu: Police avert political tiff at paddy procurement centre
Article:
Palamu police did ‘political containment’, other than the coronavirus containment, as Palamu district continues to be negative for this dreaded virus here so far.

Sources said police contained a minor issue snowballing into a major political issue at FCI’s paddy procurement centre (PPC) where one Sachidanand Chourasia alias Munna had a tiff with FCI’s programme officer A K Diwaker forcing FCI’s godown manager Solan Dangal of this PPC to rush to Chainpur police station for lodging an FIR against this Munna.

Sources said farmers have started bringing in paddy to this centre along with 12 others also in Palamu and this incident could have cast a shadow on procurement of paddy but for timely and swift action by Chainpur police station officer in charge Sunit Kumar the issue collapsed on its own.

A prompt police intervention made FCI officials Diwaker and Dangal to again write to Chainpur police station that Munna has admitted his folly and has promised not to act rudely again and thus FCI officials have reached a reconciliation with Munna thus thereby meaning their first petition for FIR against Munna goes automatically redundant.

Chainpur police OC Sunit Kumar said, “Strict police intervention saved the situation at this PPC. The day this incident occurred this PPC had done more than Rs 8 lakh procurement of paddy here which meant Munna and FCI tiff was too small.”

Sources said former minister and senior Congress leader K N Tripathy when learnt that one Chourasia had tiff with FCI officials soon sprang up to highlight this issue and rang up additional chief secretary in food and civil supplies Arun Kumar Singh as to how Chourasias are throwing spanner in paddy procurement here at Chainpur PCC.

There was no respite then as additional chief secretary rang up DC Shantanu Kumar Agrahari to look into this PPC matter, who then rang up SP Ajay Linda to do the same.

Tripathy said, “Chourasias are doing excesses. They are buying paddy from farmers at cheaper rates. They are trying to pass it off at PCC where a quintal of paddy is worth around 2,000 rupees. They are minting money by duping farmers.”

Tripathy further said, “I will not allow these Chourasias to have their way. Police must take action against them.”

Sources said there is a wedge between Tripathy and Chourasias here since November 30 polling when Tripathy was attacked by a section of these people and his multi lakh car damaged who then had to brandish his licensed revolver in his self defense. He lost to Alok Chourasia then in 2019 VS election.

The former minister Tripathy had no word that FCI officials and this lone Munna Chourasia had already patched up their ‘matter’ between them leaving police no simple thread to initiate legal action.

SP Ajay Linda said, “Police’s top priority is that paddy procurement goes on smoothly at all the13 centres in this district and FCI officials and farmers face no problem.”

SDPO Sadar Sandip Kumar Gupta said “ Under order of SP Linda we are keeping close watch over PCCs and have even deployed cops to ensure smooth paddy procurement here.”

Title: 4 held for sneaking out of Hindpiri containment zone
Article:
Police on Tuesday nabbed four men, who were allegedly trying to sneak out of Hindpiri –a Covid-19 containment zone– via Harmu. The offenders, all under the age of 40 years, reportedly wanted to visit other parts of the city and were caught red-handed, police said.

"We have charged them (the four violators) under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code. It is a bailable offence, but it may lead to imprisonment of up to six months," said Ranchi Superintendent of Police, Saurav.

Out of 25 Covid-19 cases reported so far in Ranchi, 24 are from Hindpiri –a densely populated locality that stretches adjacent to Mahatma Gandhi Road, and connects with Pee Pee Compound on one end and Upper Bazar on the other. The locality was sealed last month after a spurt of Covid-19 cases was reported from the area, officials said. Out of the three coronavirus deaths reported in Jharkhand so far, two deceased persons were from Hindpiri.

Meanwhile, the district administration in collaboration with the Association of Health Care Providers (AHCP) launched 20 medical helpline numbers for providing assistance to locals during the ongoing lockdown.

The list of registered hospitals for this purpose includes Raj Hospital, Guru Nanak Hospital, Bhagwan Mahaveer Medica, Orchid Hospital, Santevita Hospital, Medanta, Devkamal Hospital, Baba Hospital, Arun Ortho, Shambhavi Cancer Center, Ranchi Urology, Ayushman Hospital, Siddharth Children's Hospital, DN Prasad Eye Centre, City Trust, Vivekananda and Rani Hospital

Ranchi is the worst-affected city in Jharkhand amid the coronavirus pandemic. More than half of the Covid-19 cases reported in the State so far are from the capital. Besides Hindpiri, a case has also been reported from Bero in suburban Ranchi.

The district administration, however, has been running aggressive sanitisation campaigns across the city with the support of GAIL(India). It is also distributing ration among residents of containment zone and running mobile ATM services. Ranchi was also one of the few districts here to launch helpline numbers for mental health assistance during the lockdown.

Title: Ranchi Press Club begins screening of journalists
Article:
For journalists working in the field amid the global pandemic, a screening drive was conducted at the Ranchi Press Club on Tuesday and the scribes were also given protective gear for their field work. The entire premise was also sanitized.

“In view of the increasing number of Cornonavirus cases, screening of journalists was done at the Press Club and over 50 people were screened on the first day where the health status for all was found to be normal,” said Press Club President Rajesh Kumar Singh.

Joint Secretary Javed Aktar said that the scanning machine has been given as a mark of support for journalists by social worker Rajesh Singh. Masks, sanitizers and soaps were also distributed amongst the media personnel.

Singh also stated that interested media men can get themselves scanned at the venue from 12 noon onwards on Wednesday as well. For the safety and protection of the reporters and photo journalists, a sanitization drive was also carried out at the premises by Rajgarhia Ventures

“Journalists too are acting as Corona warriors and their safety is very important. The interiors and exteriors of the Club have been sanitized to curb the spread of the virus,” said Ashwini Rajgarhia from Rajgarhia Ventures.

Singh expressed his gratitude to the sanitization team and said that the efforts being made for the protection of journalists are commendable. The Club will be sanitized at regular intervals using drone system. Executive members of the Club Prashantt Kumar, Sunil Gupta, Sunil Poddar have also played a key role in the sanitization drive.

Title: Man commits suicide over Covid-19 fear
Article:
A 42-year-old man allegedly committed suicide by jumping off the third floor of a private nursing home in Ranchi over fears that he had contracted the coronavirus disease, police said on Tuesday. The man resident of Hundru village under Airport police station was put on quarantine at Lake View Nursing Home in Bariatu area.

Sources said that after the man in the morning jumped from the third floor of the nursing home he was admitted at Rajendra Institute of Medical Sciences (RIMS) where he succumbs to his injuries in the afternoon. Police sources said that as he was put on quarantine he feared that he infected with Covid-19, due to which, he was under depression for past few days.

Bariatu police station, SHO said, “The man had suffered multiple injuries on his body. Due to excessive blood loss he died.” Sources said that the man was under depression for past few days as he feared that he had corona positive. The man who works as driver at Airport was put on quarantine after he came in contact with suspected corona patients. The man few days back had drove an elderly man to airport from his residence in Bariatu.

The elderly man who was retired DDC died due to coronavirus in Delhi, but had treatment at several hospitals and private clinics in State Capital.

Bariatu police station, SHO said, “The body will be handed to family members after corona test of the victim.” Sources said that Health ministry has set up guidelines for handing over the body of the corona patient.

Sources said that there some standard precautions to be followed by health care workers while handling dead bodies of Covid 19 patients as per directions of ministry of health department.

The health worker attending to the dead body should perform hand hygiene, ensure proper use of PPE (water-resistant apron, goggles, N95 mask, gloves). All tubes, drains and catheters on the dead body should be removed.

Any puncture holes or wounds (resulting from the removal of the catheter, drains, tubes, or otherwise) should be disinfected with 1 per cent hypochlorite and dressed with impermeable material. Also, while handling sharps such as intravenous catheters and other sharp devices and oral, nasal orifices of the dead body should be plug to prevent leakage of body fluids.

Sources said that this is second case of suicide of person fearing coronavirus. On Monday, a youth and government school teacher had committed suicide by hanging self from ceiling fan of his house in Giridih district.

The man had left a three page suicide note addressed to Prime Minister Narendra Modi in which he had mentioned that he fears that he is infected with coronavirus and committing suicide so that the virus doesn’t spread to other persons.

Title: Corona ‘victim’ buried at Doranda cemetery
Article:
Unlike last week when performing last rites of a COVID -19 victim had become a real issue and challenge for district administration, the corpse of a patient, who was tested positive earlier and died on Tuesday was buried at Doranda cemetery without any hiccups. As precautionary measures police personnel along with senior administrative officials were present at Doranda cemetery.

The 54-year old woman who was infected with Coronavirus died on Tuesday morning at Rajendra Institute of Medical Sciences (RIMS). The woman was admitted at RIMS on April 6 and was suffering from kidney ailments. The woman had undergone dialysis twice, but on Tuesday her health deteriorated. The widow’s husband died last week, but his burial witnessed protests at Ratu Road Kabristhan and Joda Talab graveyard.

Ranchi SDM Lokesh Mishra said, “The woman’s final rites and burial took place at the Doranda cemetery.” The SDM said that all the protocols were followed in performing the final rites of the woman.

Sources said that only handful of persons were allowed to participate at the final rites of the woman. Also, while performing the last rites special precautions were taken so that there was no direct contact of corpse with any living persons.

The corpse of a corona positive patient was denied burial in the local Ratu Road cemetery and Joda Talab area.

Throwing the social distance advisory in wind, at least 200 people had gathered and protested outside Kabristhan against the Ranchi district administration's decision to bury the body in the graveyard. They also demanded that the corpse be buried somewhere else. The protesters had claimed that corona infection can spread if the body was buried at the cemetery. Later the body was buried at a cemetery at Hindpiri area.

Learning from last experience the district administration decided to perform the last rites of woman at Doranda cemetery based on consent provided by religious leaders.

The Ranchi district administration had talks with Anjuman Islamia regarding burial of dead bodies of corona patient. The district administration had given three to four places (graveyards) options were the corona patient burial had to take place.

Meanwhile, the ministry of health and family welfare in India has issued guidelines for its citizens about how to dispose of the body of a suspected or confirmed case of Covid-19.

As the main driver of transmission of COVID-19 is through droplets there is increased risk of COVID infection from a dead body to health workers or family members. As per guidelines the crematorium or burial ground staff should be sensitised that Covid-19 does not pose additional risk.

The guidelines also allow religious rituals such as reading from holy books or scriptures, sprinkling holy water and other last rites that do not require touching of the body.

However, bathing, kissing and hugging of the dead body is prohibited.

Title: Social distancing should be practiced in classrooms- Motherhood Uni VC
Article:
Noted academician and Vice Chancellor (VC) of Motherhood University, Roorkee, Haridwar, Narendra Sharma believes that the academic institutions across the world should make suitable changes in their structural set up and functioning to conform themselves to the prescribed social distancing norms in order to prevent spread of novel Coronavirus (COVID-19). Talking to The Pioneer, Sharma said that it is clear that the world would have to learn to live with the dreaded virus so it is prudent that everyone makes necessary changes so that the disease is kept at bay. “The educational institutes which are closed at the moment would open once the government makes a decision. We should make necessary changes in our class rooms, lecture theatres, libraries, laboratories, assembly halls and other places so that the necessary social distancing is followed. We would have to change the sitting plan of the classrooms to make them accommodate less number of students. Every institution would have to make changes. We have already started work in this direction,’’ he said.

The VC added that the Motherhood University has started online classes in all disciplines from April 9 so that the studies of the students are not drastically hampered. “Though the online classes cannot replace normal classrooms but under the prevailing circumstances where everything is closed, they are best option. We have prepared an elaborate schedule for these classes which start at 10 am and continue till 6 pm,’’ he said.

Sharma opined that one should not get swayed and make opinions based on what is streaming on the social media platforms. He said that many a times the information on such platforms are false and mischievous. Sharma said that the advisory issued by the Prime Minister, Chief Minister, administrations, doctors should be followed. He said that the people should follow simple methods mentioned in Ayurveda and Yoga to strengthen their immune system and body. On being asked about the problems faced by the university administration due to the long lockdown enforced to flatten the infection cycle of the virus, Sharma admitted that arranging finance is a problem as fees from the students is not being collected. He however praised the management of the institution for making necessary arrangements for paying salary of the staff and other expenditure during these hard times. “We have decided that no one would be shown the exit door and no salary would be deducted during this period of crisis,’’ he said.

On the impact of the crisis on placements this year, the VC accepted that he foresees a fall of 20 per cent in placement as the industry would cut recruitment.

He said that the University would donate a sum of Rs 2 lakh to the PM CARES fund as token of its responsibility towards the nation. “One of our board of governors, Rajesh Diwan was among the first to open the strings of his purse. He had donated Rs 30 lakh to PM CARES fund and Rs 20 lakh to CM (Delhi) relief fund. Our university is ready for everything it can to contribute its bit in the fight against the disease,’’ he claimed.

Title: Chhattisgarh seeks Rs 30K cr from Centre
Article:
Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel in a letter on Tuesday requested Prime Minister Narendra Modi to provide financial assistance of Rs 30,000 crore to the State in the next three months for relief and welfare schemes in view of the Covid-19 pandemic.

Baghel also requested the Central Government to relax economic activities related to revenue generation in the state.

In his letter, the chief minister has requested the PM to immediately release Rs 10,000 crore so that financial assistance can be extended to to industries, businesses, service and agriculture sectors.

The CM also requested for exemption for opening of sweet shop, sale of properties, showrooms of vehicles, construction work in cities, showrooms of domestic appliances, repairing works and all retail outlets in the green districts

Baghel in his letter said that exemption should be given to open sweets shops, so that dairy farmers can sell milk.

The CM said that due to the long period of the lockdown, revenue collections have come down to almost zero in the state.

In the current economic scenario, there is also a big reduction in the amount that the state receives from central taxes, the CM said and added that the state government will need additional resources for the livelihoods of the 56 lakh poor and needy families of the State, who have no means of income left.

Title: 2 Lakh labourers registered through App to get assistance: CM
Article:
Chief Minister Hemant Soren today said that around two lakh labourers have registered themselves in the Mukhyamantri Suvidha App launched with the aim to facilitate the labourers stuck outside the State during lockdown. He said that very soon Rs 1000 each will be transferred to the labourers through DBT in their bank accounts.

The CM, speaking during the launch of another App to facilitate people of the State to buy food items online during the lockdown here on Tuesday said that the shortcomings of the App have been removed and it has been registered with Google Playstore. The government is working continuously to serve the interests of poor, farmers, labourers and every resident of the State, he said.

Soren said that people should not come out of the houses in lockdown and supply of food grains to them should be ensured. “For the convenience of the people of Municipal Corporation, Nagar Panchayat, City Council, the Jharkhand Bazar App is being launched. The purpose of launching the App is to provide food grains in lockdown to people living in small and big cities. The effective way to avoid infections like corona is following social distance. In such a situation, this app will prove to be effective for the people of the state,” he said during the launch of Jharkhand Bazar App prepared by the Department of Food, Public Distribution and Consumer Affairs here on Tuesday.

The App can be downloaded by going to Google Playstore of Android mobile. One can also install mobile app through URL- https://bit.ly/34Lm5cC. After registration or login in the App, it will provide a list of shops, shopkeeper's names and contact number falling within the radius of two kilometers of the location of the consumer.

Supply of food grains through the app can be done through home delivery. In the absence of home delivery facility, the App will issue M-pass, which will have a time period for making purchases. The delivery person will also issue an M-Pass for home delivery. This App will not work in areas with hotspots.

Meanwhile, CM said that lakhs of people are being fed every day across the State in lockdown through 6628 Chief Minister Didi Kitchens, community kitchens in police stations, Chief Minister Kitchen and centers run by working people. “This model of our state is now being adopted by other state governments as well,” he said.

Ministers Dr Rameshwar Oraon, Badal, Chief Secretary Sukhdeo Singh, Additional Chief Secretary Arun Kumar Singh, DGP MV Rao, Principal Secrteary to CM Rajiv Arun Ekka, Principal Secretary Vinay Kumar Chaubey, IPRD Director, Rajiv Lochan Bakshi, Senior Private Secretary to CM Sunil Srivastav alongwith other officials were present on the occasion.

Title: Covid-19 patient dies after testing negative: Officials
Article:
A 54-year-old Hindpiri woman, who lost her husband to Covid-19 earlier this month and was herself under observation after testing positive for the virus, died on Tuesday even as her sample before her death tested negative, health officials said.

This is said to be the third coronavirus death in Jharkhand following death of a 75-year-old man in Bokaro and a 60-year-old man in Ranchi.

However, Health Secretary Nitin Madan Kulkarni said that the woman's samples tested negative for coronavirus before her death. "She was a patient of cardiomyopathy and kidney ailments. We cannot officially count it as a Covid-19 death," said Kulkarni.

Sources from the health department said that at least four members of the deceased woman's family have tested positive for Covid-19 .

The total number of infected members in the family was six before the woman and her spouse lost their battle against coronavirus, sources said.

Meanwhile, no new cases of coronavirus were reported in Jharkhand on Tuesday –a development that comes as a relief after a surge reported in the number of cases almost every day in the month of April, health officials said. "No new cases were reported today (Tuesday)," said Kulkarni.

By now, at least 45 cases of Covid-19 have been reported in Jharkhand. Out of the total 45 cases reported in Jharkhand so far, 25 are from Ranchi, 11 from Bokaro, three from Hazaribag, three from Simdega, and one each from Koderma, Deoghar, Giridih. Out of these patient, three have died, health officials said. Out of the three deceased, two were from Ranchi and one from Bokaro.

As per the daily Covid-19 bulletin issued by the National Health Mission (NHM), the Government collected samples of 6188 coronavirus suspects by Tuesday. Out of these samples, 4700 have tested negative, the bulletin said.

At least four coronavirus patients in Jharkhand have recovered completely from their ailments till date, health officials said.

Two of the four patients who recovered from the lethal viral infection are from Hazaribag, while the remaining two are from Simdega and Ranchi respectively, they added.

Title: 135 licensed liquor shops sealed
Article:
Amidst ongoing lockdown, the administration has sealed all the 135 licensed liquor shops across the East Singhbhum district. The administration is also keeping an eye on these shops and the owners have been warned that not a single bottle of liquor can be taken out of these sealed shops.

Meanwhile, concerned over the seizure of duplicate liquor continuously, Manoj Kumar, excise assistant commissioner, Jamshedpur has called upon the people not to consume the kind of Indian made foreign liquor available through bootleggers.

"We have been receiving complains from different corners so we have increased vigil of 135 licensed liquor shops across the East Singhbhum district. If anyone comes up with any liquor bottle for sale, claiming it to be genuine one, then one should be cautious," said Kumar.

He admitted that several businessmen have started making IMFL of popular brand unauthorisedly in a clandestine manner for taking an undue advantage of the situation in which scores of people crave for liquor in the steel city and beyond.

"We are conducting raids and have seized the consignment of spurious liquor either at the place where it is manufactured or on way. But despite the knowledge that all the liquor shops are closed, a section of people still buying liquor by putting their lives at risk," said the assistant commissioner.

Though sale of liquor has completely stopped since the lockdown came into effect on March 25, liquor bottles are finding their ways to the boozers clandestinely across steel city. Various popular brands of the Indian made foreign liquor (IMFL) is being sold at a premium. A popular brand of liquor, MRP of which is Rs 900, is being sold at a price ranging between Rs 1,200 and Rs 1,600 a bottle. But the liquor bottles are changing hands to the ultimate users only through 'reliable' people.

“Illicit liquor is a hugely profitable industry where bootleggers pay no taxes and sell enormous quantities of their product. There is a need to restrict extensive abuse of the intoxicant in order to reduce untoward incidents in the society. Continuous raids must be carried against illegal distilleries especially in view of lockdown,” noted another official.

Notably, the steel city has a history of manufacturing of duplicate liquor as the district police had in the past busted several rackets of duplicate liquor manufacturing units, especially from the localities like Bagbera, Jugsalai and Kadma.

Title: ESL, CII distribute dry ration, safety kits among leprosy patients
Article:
Vedanta-Electrosteel Steels Limited (ESL) along with Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) has stepped up for a contribution to fighting coronavirus pandemic among the poor and needy.

Taking this effort forward, today we have distributed 30 days dry ration and sanitizer kit to 80 leprosy patients of Baba Amte Leprosy Center, Khusro (Gomia) in association with the CII under relief and rehabilitation, informed ESL PR official.

Dry ration, soap and mask were also distributed among 170 leprosy patients Bhojudih Leprosy Center, Chandankiyari, he said.

Keeping in mind the social distance, the CSR department of ESL also conducted an awareness campaign to avoid COVID 19, which aims to protect people from the outbreak of COVID 19.

Our goal is to save the country and work for the needs of the country.

COVID-19 has taken the form of a huge epidemic in the country. The whole country is taking the necessary steps together to avoid this epidemic. We (ESL) are trying hard to reduce the epidemic in people.

Title: New hands free sanitisation facility at BSL
Article:
BSL management is providing new facilities to its employees for sanitization at workplace to prevent Covid-19. Recently two sanitization chambers have been set up in the plant premises which are being taken advantage of by steel workers. In this series, a hands free soap and water dispenser equipment dedicated for the use of steel workers at the steel building complex in the presence of BSL ED (P&A) Mukul Prasad, ED (Projects) R. Kushwaha, ED (MM) VK Pandey and ED (Finance and Accounts) D K Saha .

The construction of hands free soap and water dispensers is a reflection of the creativity of the team of the Municipal Administration of Water Supply Department, which has been made entirely by internal resources of this team.

This device, created under the guidance of Deputy General Manager AK Avinash where Setup having the facility of using water on one side and soap by foot pedal on the other side without having any use of hand which is key factor of this device.

There is a plan to introduce this innovative facility of sanitization soon in other major office buildings including BGH.

Title: Jharkhand girl’s venture provides experts’ opinion for cancer patients
Article:
Amidst the global pandemic, cancer patients who have low immunity levels are very vulnerable to infection and subsequent complications. With the country in lockdown and hospitals only treating emergency cases, Navya -- a clinical informatics company -- aims to bridge the gap between cancer patients, care givers and world class oncologists by providing them treatment plans online.

Founded by Jamshedpur girl Gitika Srivastava (40) in 2014, Navya is a clinical informatics company based in Bangalore. Founded in collaboration with Tata Memorial Centre (TMC) and National Cancer Grid (NCG) it provides online expert opinion to cancer patients.

“During the Coronavirus outbreak, our daily volumes have doubled or tripled as in cancer timing of treatment is very important. Navya offers a 24- hour turnaround to patients as their anxiety levels decreases by about 97 percent when they know the treatment plan within one day,” said Srivastava.

Aimed with a goal to reach each and every cancer patient and empowering them with information and clarity when they are faced with the challenge of making complex medical decisions, it also ensures that patients get an expert opinion irrespective of their location and are able to continue with the line of treatment at a hospital of their choice.

“When a close family member was diagnosed with cancer in 2007, opinions from several oncologists over emails, phone calls, in person meetings were rounded up. We spend several hours on research and asked numerous questions to understand the language the ‘medical speak’. It was an ordeal to get the best of everything- information, treatment option and recommendation by the best doctor. This is where Navya was born,” added the Founder.

In a short time span over 50,000 patients from 74 countries have reached out to Navya and received a range of benefits from knowing the next step in cancer management to free information on diagnostics, side effects and care protocol to receiving a multidisciplinary treatment plan from the world’s best experts. Patients range from rural to urban areas as well as socioeconomically underprivileged to business executives.

“In the coming years, we aim to partner with every major hospital, insurance companies and the government of India so that patients can be ensured of receiving the latest recommendations. We also wish to partner with local treating centres and hospitals across the country as part of NCG so that oncologists can collaborate with their specialist colleagues and ensure that the treatment delivered is standarised,” added Srivastava.

Born in Jamshedpur, Srivastava completed her schooling from Loyala High School and is currently based in Boston, USA and shuffles between the USA, Geneva and India. She is a graduate in computer science and engineering from Harvard and an MBA from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) Sloan.

Her parents have now retired and settled in Gurgaon. While her father Pradeep Srivastava was a national level basketball player, her mother Dr Nalini Srivastava was a professor at Graduate School College for Women in Jamshedpur.

Her Husband Nilesh Singh, who also hails from the Steel City, is an Assistant Director at Proctor & Gamble and shuffles between Boston and Geneva.

Title: WCD Min discusses ways to provide food to women, kids under ICDS programme
Article:
Minister for Social Welfare Rajendra Pal Gautam on Tuesday called a meeting of the Department of Social Welfare and Department of Women and Child Development to discuss the possibility of providing ration and other nutritional food supplements to women and children who are a part of Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) Programme.

"There are several women and children who are dependent on Anganwadis for basic nutrition and primary healthcare needs. In view of the nationwide lockdown due to the spread of coronavirus, Anganwadi workers are providing primary healthcare facilities right at the doorsteps of pregnant women and children. In these difficult times, they need more nutritious supplements also to meet their basic health requirements. I have asked the officials to explore the possibilities of replacing panjiri and other items given to Anganwadi children with more nutritional supplements like peanuts and sprouted grams," Gautam said.

During the meeting, the Cabinet Minister lauded the work done by Anganwadi workers who are doing tremendous work to help women and children by providing them with basic nutritional facilities right at their doorstep.

"All our social workers especially the Anganwadi workers are corona warriors. They are going door to door to create awareness regarding coronavirus. They are also providing food and other supplements to pregnant women and children. In this crucial time, they are our heroes," he said.

The minister also assessed the work done by the Department of Social Welfare during the lockdown in helping people receive timely pensions which includes senior citizens, Differently-abled and widow pensions.

It may be noted that during the nationwide lockdown, the Delhi Government has announced doubling the pensions for senior citizens, widows and differently-abled citizens.

Title: L-G: Give quality food to workers in shelter home
Article:
Delhi Lieutenant Governor Anil Baijal on Tuesday visited a shelter home in the national Capital where migrants daily wage workers are accommodated, and asked the officials to constructively engage people and explore options for physical fitness while maintaining social distancing norms and ensure good quality timely food.

Baijal said the basic amenities in the shelter homes were being provided by the district administration and the DUSIB. "Visited shelter for stranded migrant labourers and DUSIB night shelter. Took stock of situation & interacted with residents there. Basic amenities are being provided by the district administration & DUSIB," he said.

“Urged the officers to constructively engage people, explore options for physical fitness/recreation maintaining social distancing norms and ensure good quality timely food. Health deptt to plan for rapid testing,” Baijal said in a series of tweets.

It may be noted that several schools in Delhi have been converted into shelter homes to provide accommodation to the stranded daily wage labourer amid the lockdown.

Baijal also said that he held a meeting with Chief Minister, Deputy Chief Minister, Districts Magistrates and Deputy Commissioners of Police and reviewed enforcement of lockdown. “Held video conference with DMs, DCPs, Hon’ble CM @ArvindKejriwal, DyCM, CS Delhi & other officers. Reviewed enforcement of lockdown, Testing, home quarantine, management of containment zones, night shelters & food centres,” he tweeted.

The Lieutenant Governor advised field officials to jointly ensure effective management of containment zones, food centres and night shelters strictly as per protocols of ‘Ministry of Health and Family Welfare’ and ‘Ministry of Home Affairs’.

Baijal further directed to monitor containment zones closely, use technology, engage local leaders and volunteers, ensure adherence to testing/surveillance protocols especially in hot spots and facilitate supply chain of essential services and goods.

He also advised the health department to plan rapid testing for frontline workers and vulnerable population.

Title: 2 ‘Congress’ youth workers held for smuggling liquor
Article:
The Delhi Police has arrested two men for allegedlly smuggling liquor in the national Capital. The duo suspected to be Congress youth wing functionaries was arrested on Sunday night near Delhi-Gurugram border. However, Indian Youth Congress president Srinivas BV dubbed the arrest a "conspiracy" which, he claimed, was aimed at defaming his organisation's relief work to help the poor during the ongoing lockdown.

Meanwhile, the national media in-charge, Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), Rohit Chahal, tweeted "The duo who were arrested by Delhi Police were members of Indian Youth (IYC) Congress Congress the car which was used for transporting the liquor belongs to IYC, President Srinivas"

According to police, the duo has been identified as R Shravan Rao (34), a resident of Hyderabad and Manish Baraj (24), a resident of Banglore.

"On Sunday night, around 9 PM specific inputs were received that a Mahindra Scorpio car, carrying illicit liquor would be coming from Gurugram side and will be entering Delhi from National Highway-8," stated the First Information Report (FIR).

"A trap was laid and duo was apprehended near Rajokri. During checking, police recovered 12 bottles of liquor for sale in Haryana only from the car," stated the FIR

"The duo was also carrying a movement pass issued for the essential services, amid the lockdown. A case under section 33/8 Delhi Excise Act and they were placed under arrest," said the police official privy to investigation adding that further probe is underway.

Title: Hindu Rao hospital distributes 400 PPE kits to medical staff
Article:
The Hindu Rao Hospital of North Delhi Municipal Corporation (NMC) on Tuesday distributed 400 ‘Personal Protection Kit’ (PPE) kits and coveralls to medical staff dealing with Covid-19 patients.

A senior NMC official said that the PPE kits were donated by Indraprastha Vishwa Hindu Parishad to the hospital. “The hospital will soon get two ventilators from Prayas foundation. These will add to the resources of the hospital and strengthen it in combat against corona virus (Covid-19). Additional Commissioner Dr Rashmi Singh said that initiative by the NMC is to ensure the safety of the foot soldiers working on ground is given due care for which model of docking centres has been created as first of its kind in the country. “These centers would be strengthened with interventions like proper training and sensitization to the DOs and DON'ts involved. These measures are taken to boost the morale of the staffs and improve their efficiency,” he added.

Title: G’gram gets 750 rapid testing kits to curb Covid
Article:
The Gurugram district received 750 rapid testing kits to contain Covid-19. With the help of these kits, the health department conducted rapid antibody tests on five corona suspected patients in Sohna and all were found negative.

However, the rapid test was not a confirmatory test for Covid-19 but helped in quickly isolating the person testing positive to prevent the spread of the disease.

Gurugram so far has registered 37 Covid-19 positive cases, of which the highest number (14 cases) has been reported from Sohna.

The 14 cases in Sohna includes 10 Tablighi Jamaat attendees, who are natives of Himachal Pradesh.

The remaining patients are those who came in close contact with an Alwar-based Covid-19 patient. They worked together for a Mewat-based firm.

“We have received 750 RTKs in the first phase and the health department has started a test of patients suspected of coronavirus with these kits. Normally where it took 3 days to confirm the suspected patient, now though these kits the corona the suspected patient is identified in just half an hour and the biggest advantage of these kits is that it is very easy to use,” said Amit Khatri deputy commissioner, Gurugram. On Friday, the Haryana Government had received 10,000 RTKs from the central Government. As per the plan, blood tests to detect coronavirus antibodies through RTKs will be done at three Covid-19 hotspot districts – Gurugram, Nuh and Hathin in Palwal. Health officials said that those with symptoms of cold, fever and cough will be tested via the kits. And containment and high-risk zones are the propriety areas.

There is six contamination zone in the city which include Devil Lal Colony, Sun City Sector 54, Sector 39, Fazilpur village in Jharsa, Village Raipur in Sohna and Ward no. 11 Pataudi.

The health officials said the demand for more testing kits will be forward as the requirement arises.

Title: 3 held for supplying liquor
Article:
The Delhi Police in separate incidents have arrested three men for allegedly supplying illicit liquor in the national Capital from neighbouring state Haryana.

In the first incident, police were patrolling at Dariyapur Village in Dwarka district on Monday around 12.15 pm and received a tip-off regarding a car carrying illicit liquor.

"Thereafter, a trap was laid at Dariyapur Village and one person was arrested. He was identified as Jitender, a resident of Dariyapur Village. He was carrying 20 cartons of illicit liquor," said a senior police officer.

"During interrogation, it was disclosed that the liquor was brought from Bahadurgarh and the consignment was to be delivered in Western Delhi," he said.

In the second incident, police arrested a 29-year-old man from near Singhu border.

According to police, on Monday around 5 pm, police nabbed Amit, a resident of Sonipat District in Haryana, at Singhu Border.

"He had curfew pass for essential services on the windscreen of the car. A total of 17 cartons were found loaded in the car," said police.

In other incident, police were checking at Singhu border and noticed a car approaching from Haryana side on Monday around 9.40 pm.

The driver was signalled to stop, but he tried to esacpe. Police pushed barricade in front of the car and overpowered the driver, officials said.

The accused has been identified as Dinesh Pal (38), a resident ofJahangirpuri. Six cartons of illicit liquor were found loaded in his car, police added.

Title: Seven Bihar workers leave Capital on bicycles, stopped’
Article:
The Delhi Police on Monday night intercepted seven labourers who were trying to cross Jheel Khurd border on bicycles to reach their village in Bihar amid ongoing lockdown.

According to Atul Kumar Thakur, the Deputy Commissioner of Police (DCP), South district, the labourers were staying at a rented accommodation in Gadda colony in Sultanpur village in South Delhi's Fatehpur Beri.

"When intercepted by police, the labourers revealed they all are residents of Madhubani, Bihar and wanted to go back to their village since they had no work here due to lockdown," said the DCP.

"However, when asked if they were facing any difficulty here, they stated they were provided with ration and we're also getting food and nor their landlord demanded rent but since they did not have any work due to lockdown, they wanted to go home," said the DCP.

"However, they were counselled by the police and were dropped to their rented accommodation and the concerned beat staff has been briefed to keep watch on them," the DCP added.

Last Tuesday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi extended the lockdown till May 3, saying it is very necessary to contain the spread of the coronavirus pandemic in the country.

Title: inbrief
Article:
Blood donation camp held

Social organization ‘Ek Kadam Rashtra ke Naam’ has been distributing food among the needy people for the last 20 days due to the global disease caused by global disease, more than two thousand needy people are receiving food from this camp every day. Suresh Sahu, the founding member of the institution, said that due to lack of blood at RIMS, patients are facing a lot of trouble. When we came to know that the doctors of RIMS are also donating blood, we decided to serve the patients by donating our blood. So today we have donated blood by organizing a blood donation camp. Today, members of our organization ‘Ek Kadam Rashtra ke Naam’ participated in blood donation camp. Among those who donated blood are mainly Suresh Sahu, Namkum Police Station Incharge Praveen Kumar Hira Prasad. Banmali Mandal, Hrithik Raj. Mahesh Agrawal, Rajesh Aggarwal, Rajesh Kumar, Pradeep Sahu, Indira Kumari, Ramesh Sharma, Ganesh Kumar, Jugnu Sahu, Ankur Kataruka, Dharmendra Singh, Santosh Kumar were among many members.

Title: 2 Cong rebels in Chouhan Cabinet; all 5 get ‘Covid’ regions
Article:
Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan here on Tuesday formed his mini Cabinet appointing five Ministers in a simple function held at Raj Bhavan. After assuming office on March 23, Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan was functioning alone and Opposition Congress was persistently attacking him for not selecting Ministers amid massive corona outbreak.

However, as the small Cabinet was sworn in at Raj Bhavan, it was quite evident that instead of accommodating seniors, the party high command clearly went for caste equations and satisfying Jyotiraditya Scindia camp. Those included in the Cabinet are-- Narottam Mishra and Govind Singh Rajput from general category, Meena Singh from Scheduled tribe, Kamal Patel from OBC and Tulsiram silawat from scheduled caste.Silawat and Rajput are Scindia loyalists and were Ministers in Kamal Nath Government. Meanwhile, senior MLAs including Gopal Bhargav, Rajendra Shukla, Bhupendra Singh, Yashodhara Raje Scindia, Gauri Shankar bisen and Rampal Singh where considered for cabinet birth but the party high command instructed for a small cabinet, sources claimed.Besides, including Bisahu Lal Singh, Mahendra Sisodiya and Prabhu Ram Chaudhari who had switched over to BJP from Congress have been kept in the waiting list.

Portfolio allocation for these ministers is likely to take place soon and the sources claimed that these five ministers could be handed over two ministries each in Shivraj Government. It is believed that the Shivraj government could expand the cabinet in May first week.Notably, in the 230 member Madhya Pradesh assembly, there could be a total of 34 ministers in the state.The main opposition Congress Party was persistently attacking the Shivraj government for running a one man show despite state being in the grip of massive Corona outbreak.

Rajyasabha MPs, Kapil Sibal and Vivek Tankha had on Monday written to President of India on Monday urging him to intervene in the matter of state government functioning without Council of Ministers 'against constitutional norms.'Former leader of opposition in the State Assembly Gopal Bhargav claimed that the party has taken the call on the cabinet formation and he hoped those selected would contribute in the fight against coronavirus.It is believed that Chief Minister Chouhan would have a tough time in future while picking up is ministerial colleagues as aspirations are high among BJP MLA besides those who switched over from Congress to BJP and allies also.

Title: CM distributes works among new ministers
Article:
Within few hours after five Ministers were administered oath, Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan distributed works among the new Ministers.

Narottam Mishra has been given responsibility of Bhopal and Ujjain Divisions, while Tulsi Silavat would have responsibility of Indore and Sagar divisions. Similarly, Govind Singh Rajput will shoulder the responsibility of Gwalior-Chambal divisions. Meena Singh has been made in-charge of Shahdol division.

Title: 3 docs, 19 nurses put in quarantine in Jajpur
Article:
As many as three doctors and 19 nurses have been placed under quarantine in Jajpur district after they came in contact with COVID-19 patients, informed district Collector Ranjan Kumar Das on Tuesday.

The doctors and nurses had come in contact with the COVID-19 positive persons at an OPD of a hospital, for which they have been put in quarantine at the Jajpur Covid Care centre, he said.

Their swab samples have been collected and sent for test. Family members of the doctors and nurses have been asked to be under home quarantine, Das said,

Notably, a total of seven persons of the district have tested positive for COVID-19 so far while one of them has been cured and discharged from hospital. As many as five persons from the district had tested positive for the virus on Monday.

Title: 5 more test +ve in Baleswar
Article:
Five more persons tested COVID-19 positive in Baleswar district on Tuesday taking the total tally to 79 in the State, the Health and Family Welfare Department said.

As per the department, the fresh five cases are close relatives of the persons, who had tested positive for the virus earlier. The cases include two 34-year-old women, a 34-year-old man, a 26-year-old man and a 12-year-old boy. The cases were termed as community transmission. The patients, who are close relatives, were suspected to reside in nearby places or in a joint family system.

Meanwhile, contact tracing of the coronavirus positive cases is underway. It is also suspected that several close relatives of previous patients stay nearby increasing the chances of chain transmission. On Monday, two positive cases had been reported from Baleswar district which included a two-year-old girl and a 32-year-old man. With the fresh detections, the total tally reported from the district incresed to eight.

Title: State to treat dead health professionals as martyrs
Article:
Honouring the doctors and other healthcare professionals who are fighting the COVID-19, Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik on Tuesday announced that Rs 50 lakh would be provided in case of death of any public or private healthcare personnel while treating coronavirus patients.

“The State Government in convergence with the Government of India initiative will ensure that Rs 50 lakh is given for all health personnel (private and public) and members of all other support services who lose their precious lives in the fight against COVID-19,” the CM said in a video message.

The State would also treat them as martyrs and provide State funeral with State honors, he said.

A detailed scheme of awards would be instituted in recognition of their unparalleled sacrifice. The awards would be given on national days. The families of all Government personnel, medical or other, would continue to receive full salary till the date of their retirement, Patnaik said.

Further, any violence against these personnel would be treated as an act against the State. In case anyone indulges in any act that would disturb or dishonour their work, very strict criminal action would be taken against them including invoking the provisions of the National Security Act (NSA), the CM warned.

Title: Delhi Govt to feed 30L poor sans IDs
Article:
Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal on Tuesday announced free ration to additional 30 lakh poor people who have no Government identification like ration card/ Aadhar till the time they are under the impact of the global pandemic.

With this addition, nearly one crore people, which is almost half of Delhi’s population, will come under the umbrella of ‘food security’ scheme of Aam Aadmi Party.

Interacting digitally with media , Kejriwal said his Government would give free ration to around one crore people in the national capital in the wake of the coronavirus lockdown.

While Kejriwal has not specified the period till which the relief will be given but ensured ration services to poor/ needy during the corona outbreak.

“As long as the impact of coronavirus lasts and the poor are unable to earn their bread, we will ensure their food security. We have a plan in place. 71 lakh people have already been given 7.5 kg of rations. Government has now decided to distribute free ration to another 30 lakh people,” he said.

Moreover, realising the basic kitchen essentials required for meal, Kejriwal added a kit comprising - Oil, Sugar, Chikpeas, Soap.

According to Kejriwal, this kit will be given along with May month ration distribution will start from April 28/29.

To ensure, temporary workers in Delhi will stay in and have meal, the government will give 2,000 food coupons each to every MLA and MP in the city for distribution among the needy in their constituencies in the wake of coronavirus lockdown, Kejriwal added.
